main.opener: You seem like someone who notices things. What've you been picking up on lately?
variants: Noticing a lot, yeah. The city's been... off lately.
Most systems acting strange. People seem tense everywhere.
I had to follow some unusual protocols at work this week.
Feels like things changed overnight and I'm still trying to keep up.
I've been involved in some emergency measures at the Directorate.
Last week I gave a warning about the BCI’s stability. It didn’t go over quietly.
Suddenly, most of Stenograd just stopped working. Blackout, everywhere.
Paper lists instead of digital. No one really knows what’s next.
It’s exhausting, honestly.
If you mean recently, I ended up triggering the BCI shutdown myself.
The whole city lost digital access. No scores, nothing—just chaos.
We had to start handing out printed rosters. I watched people just… get stuck.
Old routines fell apart in minutes. Even the Council looked rattled.
And now a lot of eyes are on me. Not by choice.
I feel worn out, trying to make sense of what I set in motion.
Honestly, I was the one who pushed for shutting down the BCI after things got unstable.
It meant switching everything to paper. No algorithm, no automated anything.
People got anxious. Elevators stalled, trains stopped, offices just fell apart. Groups were milling in hallways, not knowing what to do.
For once, every small action had to be figured out by hand.
I wasn’t exactly praised. My score dropped again. Didn’t dare log my decisions.
I used to believe the BCI made things safer. Now I see the cracks.
It left me feeling... exposed, if that makes sense.
I spend all day analyzing so-called deviant behavior—supposed to keep order—but I’ve seen what happens when the system turns on someone for nothing.
When Halden died, everything spiraled. Secrets leaked, people panicked, and the Council just chased its own tail.
I argued we had to shut down the BCI or things would get catastrophic. No more algorithm. All analog, old-school chaos.
I ran the shutdown myself. Printed names. Manual checks. No one’s really in control—least of all me.
People who never thought about the system before are suddenly locked out. I’m... on thin ice after the Council saw what I did.
My score dropped to 16. No warnings. They made a point of it. I haven't felt this vulnerable in years.
I want things calm, ordered—like they were. I really believed BCI was right, at first. Now I’m not sure where I stand.
It’s a different city, suddenly. And I don’t know my place in it anymore.
main.emotion: A kind of tired uncertainty. Like I'm still processing it all and not sure where things will land.

emotional.opener: Sometimes the only thing you can do is breathe and let yourself feel for a moment. You’re not alone, Oksana.
variants: Yeah. I guess that’s true.
Breathing is about all I’ve managed lately.
Maybe you’re right. It’s hard not to keep it all contained.
It’s strange to even talk about it, honestly.
But… maybe that’s okay.
It helps to hear that.
I keep thinking I should have everything sorted out, but I don’t.
Feels like I’m watching the city shift and I can’t quite keep my footing.
Still, being reminded I’m not alone… it really does help.
I forget to let myself just feel anything some days. It’s like there’s no room for that here.
Hearing someone say it out loud is grounding, honestly.
I keep replaying conversations in my head, as if it’ll make sense of things.
But letting myself pause, breathe… it’s something I needed.
Thank you for that.
You know, I used to think it was all about staying composed. Keeping what you feel to yourself, like everyone else here.
But lately, that’s just felt exhausting. Like control takes more effort than I even have left.
It gets lonely, not knowing where you can let any of that out.
The city’s so structured now—sometimes it’s as if the only time I really exhale is in places like this.
I just want to remember what it felt like to be relaxed, not endlessly measuring every move.
Your words actually reminded me there are still spaces for that, for being understood. Thank you.

factual.opener: So? What actually happened out there? Everyone's talking, but no one says much. Just give it straight.
variants: Systems broke down everywhere. Nothing worked right.
People were pretty desperate for info. Confusion everywhere.
Council started talking face to face instead of through terminals.
No word yet when things will go back to normal.
City just froze after the shutdown. Long lines for everything.
Council had to improvise with paper and meetings. Haven't seen that before.
Neighborhoods are managing on their own now. Not all are handling it well.
There's a lot of talk about who should be in charge if the system stays down.
People seem unsure who to trust.
Since the blackout, the Council lost its grip. Power-sharing deals now, but they're shaky.
I've watched old processes come back—manual records, even local leaders cropping up.
Everyone's looking for someone to blame. Directorate wants control. Harmonists say let people self-organize, at least for now.
Rumors about changes to the BCI keep circling. Nothing clear yet.
Streets feel different—neighbors acting like strangers, some stepping up to help though.
Whatever stability we had is gone, at least for now.
Halden's death started it, then private leaks made things worse. Trust just crumbled.
The BCI scores stopped making sense even before the blackout—seen people act out, or just ignore the rules.
Now, without the BCI, alliances pop up everywhere. Council's public power-sharing? It's more panic control than anything real.
I know the Harmonists want calm, but Directorate pushes for total lockdown, and Innovators want to rewrite the rules from scratch.
I've seen colleagues picked apart over old data leaks. No one feels safe.
Feels like anything could tip, any moment.
Parts of the city actually work better on paper—others, it's a mess.
Honestly, this all shook whatever faith I had left in the system. I grew up thinking order was everything—never thought I'd see it unravel this way.
Halden's death hit harder than the news let on. People inside the Directorate... they lost their anchor.
Then those data leaks: everyone suddenly knows everyone else's scores and secrets. It was like the floor vanished.
BCI algorithms spun out of control. People flagged as unsafe started getting access, the compliant ones blocked. Unofficial fixes everywhere, backdoors, scams.
I watched my own department scramble—no chain of command, just panic. Even the 'power-sharing' is Council trying to stay afloat.
I stuck to the Harmonist line, hoping local groups could restore calm. Some did, others—disaster.
Residents are organizing resources themselves. It's impressive, but I still see how thin the trust is.
I'm marked noncompliant now, so I see both sides. Some want the old order back. Others never trusted it anyway. I just want the city to feel like home again.
It's strange, seeing the cracks show so clearly, after everything we built on hiding them.
